div.p: Greetings. I received your letters, dear brother, along with those you wrote to Count Martinengo; I will send them to Geneva with the first reliable courier.
I am very sorry that due to my duties, I was unable to honor Mr. Gregor Carl with my presence at some banquet. I liked that man; I had never seen him before.
I encouraged him, albeit briefly, to remain steadfast in goodness, etc.
What I received from Heidelberg and elsewhere, I share here; please return it.

Greet Mr. Bellievre most dutifully; I have conveyed to him what you have regarding the Empseran legion. Our excellent Samuel Pellican is bedridden; his wife, a most honorable matron, is also bedridden; may the Lord raise them up and preserve them.

Mr. Jodocus Brenwald's wife is bedridden without hope of life, as is his eldest daughter. Throughout the city, people are being seized and enveloped by this plague; may the Lord grant strength of spirit and true faith.
Farewell and pray to the Lord for us.
Greet the lords, the councilors, and the fellow ministers.

All the scholars and foreign students have now dispersed; the school auditoriums are empty. To the most excellent man, Mr. Johannes Fabricius, faithful minister of the Chur church, my esteemed and beloved lord and brother. Chur.
